addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England

28 A
p
1590
M
r
Bodelie to my L.
Gronighen

page.lettertext:
Right honorable and my singular good Lord,
having lost
M
r
Secretary Walsingham
, whome
I can not name unto yow, w
t
any moderat grief,
I beseeche yo
r
L. to hold me excused, that I put
yow to some troble in this addresse of my letters.
For though I am not ignorant
at yo
r
L. should
be spared in suche respectes, yet because I un-
derstand not as yet, whome her
Ma
tie
hath ap-
pointed to
e exercise of
at office, and because
the mater w
ch
I signifie, is of special conse-
quence, I trust yo
r
L. will passe it with a fa-
vorable acceptation. I doe not dout
but yo
r
L. hath bene made acquainted w
t
my
former advertisments about
e towne of Gro-
ninghen. It was an assured persuasion of
divers gentlemen of
Friseland
,
Embden
, and
other places, who writte unto me about it,
at
e inhabitants of that towne were so weary
of
e spaniard, and so wel affected to her
Ma
tie
at if those good meanes were used, w
ch
her Hig
nes
w
t
a small charge might put in
execution, they would be easely drawen to
submitte themselves unto her. Alwaies pro-
vided at they might not any way be subject to
the states of these contreis. This I cer-
tified home, w
t
all
e informac
o
ns, w
ch
I recea-
ved from
e parties. M
r
Secretary made
me answear, That her Ma
tie
by reason of her
excessive charges otherwise, would not enter into
a further expense, by sending over ether mony
or forces; but if by using her name, autoritie
fol.121v
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
and countenance, they could finde
e meanes
to w
t
stand or annoy
e Enemie, I should give
them that way w
at
encouragement I could.
The effect of this answear I imparted present-
ly to those, from whome
e motion first procee-
ded. Who signified againe, that there was no hope
of any good to be done, unles her Ma
tie
would
vouchesafe to send her letters to
e towne, promise
to maintene both them and their liberties against
their Enemies, and cause to be presented suche
further assistance and succo
rs
before
e towne,
as having revolted they might be able assuredly
to make it good against
e Enemie. Fin-
ding her Ma
tie
thus unwilling to take
e enter-
prise in hand, in respect of
e charge, and in
those of Groninghen no maner of inclination to
deale w
t
e states: considering also
at if her
Hig
nes
should attempt any thing in those q
a
rters,
w
t
out
e privitie of
e states, it would be both
hardly perfourmed, and give a great cause
of suspition to people already not
e best af-
fected, I knewe no better course, for
e conten-
tac
o
n of all parties, then to acquaint
e Councel
of state w
t
e whole mater. W
ch
I did accordingly
For I declared heere unto them w
at
offers had bin
made unto her Ma
tie
for w
at
cause she refused
them, howe willing she was that
e contrey
should take
e benefit of using her autoritie, w
at
letters had bin written unto me from sundrie
places and persons, and what answears I retur
-
ned. In effect I made as many circumstances
knowen unto them, as might induce them to advise
howe to reape
e fruit of that overture.
fol.122r
Belgia: 1590: Aprill
Wheruppon it was resolved that I should per-
sist in writing to those of Embden, and take as
perfit informac
o
n, as I could, of
e nombers of
them
at were well affected in Groninghen,
of
e meanes whiche they had to compasse their pur-
pose, w
t
suche other pointes besides, as the enter-
prise required. And this I did from time
to time to their satisfactio, alwais shewing
those letters whiche I writte and receaved.
Moreover to
e end I might
e better stand as-
sured of
e true estate of all thinges, I sent
this bearer
Christopher Persivall
, a man well ac-
qauinted in those quarters, to my frindes at Emb-
den: who of a speciall devotion to
e service,
adventured uppon his owne charge, and not w
t
out
great daunger, to approche w
t
in half a mile of
e
towne,
of Groninghen
where he taried certain daies in a village,
and had daily c
o
ference w
t
divers Burghers;
whiche resorted unto him at several times, and
gave him intelligence of
e
disposition of
e
commons, w
t
suche
other particularities, as he himself will declare.
For w
ch
good service I have put him heere in
hope,
at by yo
r
L. meanes he shalbe somwhat
considered. In one of my letters, w
ch
I
writte by him to those of Embden, I had signified
that we had certaine intelligence by letters newly
intercepted, at
e
Duke of Parma
was reso-
lutly bent, by one meanes or other, to place a
Garrison in Groninghen, and to
at purpose had
charged
Verdugo
e Governo
r
there, to take
e
first and spediest opportunitie. This letter
of mine was sent by those of Embden into
Groninghen, uppon
e sight wherof
e people cau-
sed all
e Spaniardes and Fributters in
e towne,
fol.122v
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
to
e nomber of 200 and more, to avoide presently
and w
t
all ordered
at Verdugo himself should not
come neere any port in
e night time. Not
to troble yo
r
L. w
t
a tedious rehersall of all that
hath passed,
e
Councel of state
, and likewise
Count
William
e Governo
r
of
Frise
, who hath also confer-
red both w
t
them and w
t
me in this mater, doe
apparantly finde that
e interposition of her Ma
ties
autoritie, may allure
e towne by good meanes, to
unite themselves w
t
these Provinces. And seing
her Ma
tie
to whome they should seeme to be only
addicted, will not deale for her self, nor those
of
e towne be persuaded to yeld unto
e states,
from whome
ei have revolted, it is thought
at
there is no readier way to atchieve
e enterprise
w
t
a general good liking, then to intreat her Ma
tie
to signe to that letter, or
e like in substance, as I
have sent heerew
t
to yo
r
L. whiche is written in
e Flemmishe tongue, by
e advise of
e Councel be-
ause fewe in Groninghen understand
e Frenche,
and it is very expedient,
at it should be under-
tood of
e common people. I have sent
e trans
-lation w
t
it, and likewise a letter from
e Councel
to her Hig
nes
, and an other from Count William.
It is intended,
at when
e letter whiche is desired
to be signed by her Hig
nes
shalbe returned,
S
r
Francis
Vere
, who lieth at
Disbourgh,
w
t
in one daies
jorney of Groninghen, shall joine his forces with
Count William, who are able bothe together to raise
3000 men,
e Enemie not having in all
at terr-
torie above 2000, and shall present themselves
before
e towne, sending in
e said letter by a trum-
pet or drumme. Wheruppon it is conceaved, that
if her Ma
ties
frindes be
e greater nomber, they will
fol.123r
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
presently come to capitulat: or if
ei be the
weaker part, yet finding forces w
t
out, they
will happely be able to deliver a port, or give
some other entrie unto them. Howsoever
it succeed,
e attempt hath nether charge nor
daunger,
and
in all probablitie will endommage
the Enemie in one sort or other. To animat
somewhat more those w
t
in
e towne, I have given
it out,
at I hope her Ma
tie
wilbe wonne in time,
to drawe
e trade of her Marchants Adventurers
thither, whereto
ei listen very gladly. I
can not also omitte, to make it knowen to yo
r
L.
that Count William doth persuade himself,
at
if
e enterprise take place, her Hig
nes
will be
pleased to committe
e towne to his government.
And were it otherwise, I doe assure my self,
that nether he nor
e states of Frise would in-
termeddle in this Action, but rather hinder it
by all possible meanes. Wherein to deliver my
opinion to yo
r
L. his sufficiencie considered,
against whiche there is no exception, the pre-
sent means
at he hath to assist
e towne out
of Friseland, and also
e right w
ch
he pretendeth
to
e government, as being a parcel of
at whiche
he hath in Frise, I can not for mine owne part
conceave, howe any other person, can better fitte
w
t
e people or
e place. I have made
no mention to yo
r
L. what reciprocall assur
a
ce
wilbe yelded from
e towne: but I doe plainely
perceave
at they will not admitt any Garrison.
Some cautionarie places, it is thought, they will de-
liver: w
ch
can not yet be knowen, till
e mater
come in question. And thus I have
imparted to yo
r
L. a desseigne of suche moment,
as
yow
it
may please
yow
to consider, and relate unto
fol.123v
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
her Ma
tie
procuring unto it suche dispatche of
answear, as yo
r
L. wisdome shall judge conve-
nient. I finde it very requisit
to advertise yo
r
L. that
e Councel heere hath
daily intelligence from
e towne of ostende, that there
groweth suche contention between
e Governo
r
and some of
e Captaines, at if it be not compoun-
ded in time, it may cause uppon
e soddain the
losse of
e place. I am urged uppon it to goe
thither, and to mediat some better agreement. But
because I doe presume,
at those maters are knowen
to my
LL. of
e Councel
, and will be redressed
by their autoritie, I have put them of till suche
time, as I receave an answear from yo
r
L. For
I am out of all hope to make any good atton-
ment, unles I be namely autorised unto it, aswell
from my LL. at home, as from
e Councel heere.
The last orders, whiche were sent unto
me from my LL. of
e Councel, for a general
muster to be taken of all her Ma
ties
forces, whiche
I receaved together w
t
several letters to
e seve-
rall Governo
rs
, I doe still reserve, untill the
Councel heere shall determine, to put them in ex-
ecution; w
ch
they could not sins so conveniently
doe, because her Ma
ties
forces in service lie disper-
sed in Disbourgh,
Williamstat
, And
Breda
.
But
e orders are very well liked, and shalbe
practised, w
t
e first opportunitie. It may
so falle,
at in my next to yo
r
L. I shall send
yow worde of some happy exploit uppon
e towne
of
Nieumeghen
.
Count Maurice
, Count William,
Count Overstein
, and S
r
Francis Vere are appoin-
ted to goe thither w
t
as many men as they ca n make,
which by disfournishing for
e time their Gar-
risons, will amount to
e nomber of 4000 foote
fol.124r
Belgia: 1590: Ap
r
and 400 horse. The day is assigned the
last of this moneth: and
e mater is kept so se-
cret, as
e Enemie, I trust, will be taken un-
provided.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e
Hage
. 28 A
p
90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
